title.narrative: Enhancing the Democratic Rule of Law

description.narrative: Enhancing the Democratic Rule of Law to promote peace and stability

title.narrative: Rule of Law Annual Work Plan 2014
Report to Kyrgyz Government on the Implementation of the Project
Report to Kyrgyz Government on the Implementation of the Project
Enhancing the Democratic Rule of Law

description.narrative: Project aimed at enhancing democratic rule of law to promote peace and stability.
independent political entity
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: 1.Recognized and formalized mechanism of cooperation of stakeholders on RoL for implementation issues; 2.At least 20 officials and consultative body members trained on international standards and RoL matters 3. Training program and methodology on capacity building of key RoL institutions as part of the judicial reform implementation is developed 4. Methodology on financial assessments of Judicial Laws finalized 5. Built national capacity for donor coordination 6. At least ten CSOs are engaged in the Judicial reform process and their capacity is enhanced 7. Establishment of mechanism for civil society engagement in Rule of Law implementation reform process.

1. On 29 June 2015, Kyrgyz Prime Minister has signed a Decree on the creation of the Coordination Council and of the Secretariat to oversee the development of implementation plans by the working groups. The Council is chaired by the Kyrgyz Vice Prime Minister. 2. 42 legal department representatives of 20 state institutions and Secretariat of Coordination Council (16 women and 26 men) participated in Rule of Law and Human Rights School aimed at awareness raising on international standards, Rule of Law, mandatory expertise, communication and cooperation. 3. Draft methodology and 12 training modules developed on new legislation for key RoL institutions. . 4. Methodology on financial assessment of judicial laws finalized, presented to the expert society. 40 representatives of the Ministry of Finance trained on the Methodology. 5. Coordination Council established under the Prime Ministers Office is responsible for development of implementation plans and their final financial assessment. Upon finalization of implementation plans, the Coordination Council will present the final cost of judicial reform to donor society and coordinate financial contributions. To be completed in 2016. 6. 4 CSOs engaged in the Coordination Council. To be completed in 2016. 7. To be completed in 2016. In cooperation with contracted CSO Institute for Public Analysis the Network for monitoring of judicial reform and better engagement of at least 10 civil society representatives will be established.

description.narrative: Improving the coverage and management effectiveness of Protected Areas in the Central Tian Shan Mountains

title.narrative: Improving the coverage and management effectiveness of PAs in the Central Tian Shan Mountains project
GEF: Improving the Coverage and Management Effectiveness of Protected Areas in the Central Tian Shan Mountains

description.narrative: Improving the coverage and management effectiveness of Protected Areas in the Central Tian Shan Mountains.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
To improve the coverage and effectiveness of protected areas in the Central Tian Shan Mountains so as to expand threatened species representation in the national system
Territorial coverage of SPNAs in Central Tian Shan Mountains which provide habitat for the endangered snow leopard

comment.narrative: 149,117.9 ha (Existing Sarychat Ertash reserve area)
Up to 336,119.9 ha by project end

Researchers from Biology and Soil Institute of the National Academy of Sciences of the Kyrgyz Republic have conducted the field study in the Project site. Based on the results of the literature review and obtained data from field survey Biology and Soil Institute provided the following: (i) Information on preliminary assessment of the flora, vertebrates (mammals, birds, cold-blooded animals), (ii) summary lists of flora and fauna, locations, biota, large mammals migration routes; (iii) Preliminary assessment of sacred natural sites and cultural landscapes of the Project site; Soil types; (iv)Recommendations for new establishing Khan-Tengri State Nature Park zoning and ecological corridors borders. Flora:
10 vegetation types, 457 plant species found and identified; Out of which: 5 species included in the Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic; 8 endemic species which are natural to or characteristic to this place; 11 species can be found only in the Project site in the Kyrgyz Republic. In addition, 4 mosses, 122 mushrooms, 287 lichen were found. Fauna:
100 bird species, out of which 8 species included in the Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic; 4 species included in the Red List of the IUCN; 13 species are listed in the CITES (appendix II). 22 mammals, out of which 5 species included in the Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic; 4 species included in the Red List of the IUCN; 4 species are listed in the CITES (appendix II, I). Staff of the State Agency on Environment Protection and Forestry completed a feasibility study for establishing a new PA. The socio-economic impact of the new PA was identified including: (i) socio-economic status, population growth, and land use composition measures; (ii) current use of the Project site land for agricultural and industry use and future prospect; (iii) water and mineral resources and their long-term perspective; (iv) modern use of forest and game species in the Project site and prospects; (v) anthropogenic pressures and threats to landscape, nature resources. Based on the results of the feasibility study and ecological assessment, tentatively, an area of 325,785 ha for the new park was identified, which has the potential to ensure conservation of mountain fragile ecosystems including flora and fauna along with sustainable development for local people residing around the Park. Out of 325,785 ha, 226,888.2 ha were identified for the core zone of the Park; 17,808 ha ecological stabilization zone for restoration and conservation activities; 8,323.4 ha - for tourism & recreational zone; 72,765.5 ha zone for limited economic activities, where traditional farming practices and biodiversity friendly activities are allowed. A social survey was held among local people to be impacted by the park creation, i.e. their lands will be transferred to Protected areas category. The survey involved 1,383 households, of which 75% indicated support for the establishment of the park and 17% - against its establishment.

description.narrative: Population size of snow leopard (Uncia Uncia) in Central Tian Shan shows an increasing trend

comment.narrative: Low numbers of snow leopard (unable to quantify)
By project end, target area offers permanent habitat for 5 females with cubs

During field surveys conducted by the Biology and Soil Institute, three sites in the Project area had signs of snow leopard activities. A questionnaire among local herders indicated that about 5-7 snow leopards were seen in the area. The snow leopard and its prey species habitat, migration routes, seasons, directions were developed. According to the Global Snow Leopard and Ecosystem Protection Programme that aims to identify and secure 20 landscapes across snow leopard range by year 2020, there are 23 national scale landscapes (Report of the FFI/CMS workshop Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan 1st 2nd December 2014). The Project site has been included as one of the key landscapes for show leopard conservation in the Kyrgyz Republic.

description.narrative: Threatened species representation is improved by increasing coverage and management effectiveness of PAs in Central Tian Shan
Enhanced management effectiveness of target PAs (as measured by METT)

comment.narrative:
Sarychat Ertash: 54%
Khan Tengri: 3%

Sarychat Ertash: 75% by project end
Khan Tengri: 28% by project end

No METT assessment has been conducted in the reporting period. The adopted methodology on PA effectiveness assessment and METT will be used after establishing the State Nature Park Khan-Teniri, the establishment is under negotiation with local self-governance bodies. The updated METT scores are expected to be available for the next PIR in 2016.

description.narrative: Reduction in poaching and illegal logging at target PAs (annual) per unit of patrolling effort, compared with year of initial patrolling

comment.narrative:
Illegal logging violations: 50
Poaching violations: 70
Total violations: 120
Reduction by 30%

During this reporting period: A reported reduction is by 7.5%. no illegal poaching and illegal logging in the existing Sarychat-Eertash Reserve was recorded. In the Project site area, 9 illegal poaching cases were detected by volunteer inspectors jointly with Issyk-Kel Biosphere Territory of SAEPF rangers of total penalty amount of 1,200 USD.

description.narrative: Habitat connectivity, sustainability and effectiveness of PAs in Central Tian Shan are enhanced by regulating land use in buffer zones, wildlife corridors and other intervening landscapes
Law on SPNAs provides clear guidance on establishment, management, and responsible party for PA buffer zones and wildlife corridors

comment.narrative: Current law is unclear
Legislation improved through amendments by project end

No change of the baseline indicator. According to the Law on Protected Areas of the Kyrgyz Republic (2011) there are 4 zones in the state nature parks: core zone; ecological stabilization zone; tourist-recreational zone; zone for limited economic activities. In accordance with SEAPF and Project board meeting suggestions (November, 2014) the above mentioned zones (except for the core zone) should be accepted as a buffer zone for the State Nature Park Khan-Tengri. During the reporting period the Project has reviewed the gaps in PA legislation and policy concerning establishment of zones, its regimes and ecological corridors. The Project initiated review of the Law of the Kyrgyz Republic on PA. By the Project support the following legislations were drafted: The Regulation on PA establishment in the Kyrgyz Republic, Regulation on Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic; Regulation on land use in State Nature Parks; Regulation on Ecological corridors and proposal for making amendments to Law on PA submitted to SAEPF for further endorsement. These documents are under consideration of the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic. In addition, the Project provided technical support for development of a programme and action plans on transition to sustainable development of the ecological and economic system of Issyk-Kul for 2015-2017, which was later integrated to the Sustainable Development Strategy of the Issyk-Kul region for 2015-2017 and its Action Plan for the implementation of the Sustainable Development Strategy of the Issyk-Kul region for 2015-2017, approved by order of the Plenipotentiary Representative of the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic in Issyk-Kul region dated February 9, 2015 #21 On approval of the Strategy for Sustainable Development of the Issyk-Kul region for the years of 2015- 2017. Biodiversity has been mainstreamed into the Sustainable Development Strategy of the Issyk-Kul region for 2015-2017 and its Action Plan for respective years.

description.narrative: Area over which territorial land use planning is fully aligned with requirements for regulated resource use stipulated in the management plans of PA buffer zones and corridors

comment.narrative: 0 ha

0 ha Key land owners and users in the Project site were identified. The new PA area would largely consist of the Ak-Suu rayon state land reserve 236,871.70 ha, Otradnaya local self-government body (LSGB) 23,776.3 ha, Teplklyuchenka LSGB 9,834.5 ha, Kerege-Tash LSGB 5,768.3 ha, Bory-Bash LSGB 2,068.5 ha, Oktyabr LSGB 1,785.0 ha, Ak-Bulun LSGB 6,532.6 ha, Chelpek LSGB 4,646.6 ha, Karakol forestry 34,501.5ha. Out of 325 785 ha, 4,939.9 ha are covered with forest, 12,744.3 ha occupied by pasture lands, 932.4 ha covered with water bodies, 50 ha of roads, 101,646 ha of glaciers and 205,472.4 ha refer to the other land category (rocks or stones etc.) It is expected that out of 325,785 ha, 98,896.8 ha of the Khan-Tengri Park territory will be included in its buffer zone where limited traditional economic activities for local communities are allowed. According to the legislation on land transfer of the Kyrgyz Republic, the bottom-up approach is used. Nine key land owners, LSGB agreed to the land transfer at local level. At present, PA establishment documents are being prepared for getting approval at regional and oblast levels. Taking into account recommendations of the National Academy of Science on establishment of ecological corridors to connect the new Khan-Tengri Park with the existing Sarychat-Eertash Reserve ecological corridors for migratory mammals were mapped and land owners identified. Local governments, local self-government bodies and local communities have been informed about establishing ecological corridors and its regimes. The establishment of the ecological corridors will be accomplished after approval of amendments to the Law on PAs of the Kyrgyz Republic and Regulation on Ecological Corridors, which is now under the consideration of the Kyrgyz Republic Parliament and then the Government. Guidelines on development of PA management Plan prepared by the Project were approved by the order of the SAEPF Director. Biodiversity conservation has been mainstreamed into the Sustainable Development Strategy of the Issyk-Kul region for 2015-2017 and its Action Plan.

description.narrative: Better management of hunting in buffers and corridors as reflected in percent of trophy hunting that is controlled and monitored

comment.narrative: Only 30% of trophy hunting is legal because hunters are uncontrolled and unmonitored
90% of trophy hunting is legally licensed

During the reporting period, 100% of trophy hunting was controlled and monitored in the Project site. 0 cases of violation by trophy hunters were recorded. A rangers handbook developed by the Project is under SAEPF approval. After approval, the handbook will be published and distributed to rangers and volunteer inspectors to improve their capacity in nature management.

description.narrative: Prosecution of illegal hunting in buffers and corridors

comment.narrative: Only 10% of incidents of illegal hunting successfully prosecuted
At least 50% of incidents of illegal hunting successfully prosecuted from Year 4 onwards

description.narrative: Increase in share of incomes of local communities from biodiversity-compatible alternative livelihood activities

comment.narrative: More than 60% of income comes from hunting
By project end, at least 60 % of income comes from sustainable livelihoods promoted by the project

No quantitative indicator is available at the moment. Project will be able to measure the quantitative indicator of change in share of incomes of local communities from biodiversity compatible livelihoods only in 2016. Social and economic assessment of target communities and development of Alternative Livelihood Programme has been completed.

description.narrative: Reduced hunting effort directly attributable to changes in livelihoods among hunters

comment.narrative: 500 persons hunting in the area
150 (reduced by 1/3) persons hunting by project end

No progress is reported at the moment, in line with project's workplan. Development of the Alternative Livelihood Programme has been completed and the Programme implementation will cover local communities and people. It is expected that the Project will be able to evaluate or assess the changes in livelihoods of local communities in 2016.
